item.label: Visual pathway
item.name: Visual pathway
item.description: The entire visual pathway begins in the retina and terminates in the calcarine cortex of the occipital lobe.  The components of the pathway are the optic nerve, optic chiasm, optic tract, lateral geniculate nucleus and optic radiations.

item.label: Optic nerve
item.name: Optic nerve
item.description: The Optic nerve or Cranial Nerve II consists of the axons of ganglion cells in the retina. The optic nerve axons will travel through the optic tract and then synapse in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus as well as in the pretectum.  Between the optic nerve and lateral geniculate nucleus, the nerve fibers from the nasal half of the retina cross the midline in the optic chiasm and then enter the optic tract; the nerve fibers from the temporal half of the retina do not cross, but enter the optic tract directly.

item.label: Optic chiasm
item.name: Optic chiasm
item.description: The optic chiasm is a midline structure that consists of the axons of retinal neurons located in the nasal half of each retina.  These nerve fibers travel first in the optic nerve and then cross in midline of the optic chiasm so that the input from the nasal retina of each eye (temporal visual field) projects to the contralateral optic tract and beyond in the visual pathway. Input from the temporal retina (nasal visual field) does NOT cross in the chiasm but projects through the ipsilateral visual pathway.  This partial crossing of the visual input is essential for binocular vision.

item.label: Optic tract
item.name: Optic tract
item.description: The Optic tract consists of optic nerve axons that serve the contralateral visual field.  These axons originate in the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina and terminate in the lateral geniculate nucleus as well as the pretectal area.

item.label: Lateral geniculate
item.name: Lateral geniculate_1
item.description: The lateral geniculate thalamic nucleus (LGN) deals with vision.  It receives input from the retina via the optic nerve and tract. It projects to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe (cuneus and lingual gyri) via the geniculocalcarine tract.  The geniculocalcarine tract is AKA the optic radiation and travels in both the sublenticular and retrolentricular portions of the internal capsule.

item.label: Optic radiation
item.name: Optic radation
item.description: The Optic Radiation is AKA geniculocalcarine tract. It is a massive bundle of myelinated nerve fibers that originate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the upper and lower banks of the calcarine sulcus in the occipital lobe. It travels through the sublenticular and retrolenticular portions of the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Meyer's loop
item.name: Meyer's loop
item.description: Meyer's loop is a portion of the geniculocalcarine tract or optic radiation that passes laterally beneath the lentiform nucleus and then loops through the temporal lobe before turning and traveling to the calcarine cortex.  The portion of the visual field that is represented in the fibers of Meyer's loop is the contralateral upper quadrant.  Temporal lobe lesions of Meyer's loop produce a contralateral upper quadrantanopia.

item.label: Visual cortex
item.name: Visual cortex
item.description: The portion of cerebral cortex that deals with the perception of visual information is located in the occipital lobe.  The visual cortex consists of the cuneus and lingual gyri that lie above and below the calcarine fissure.  Upper visual fields are represented in the lingual gyrus and lower visual fields are represented in the cuneus.

item.label: Cerebrum
item.name: Cerebrum
item.description: The cerebrum consists of the paired cerebral hemispheres.  Each cerebral hemisphere consists of lobes:  frontal, parietal, occipital, temporal.  In some instances a limbic lobe is designated-- consisting of a portion of the medial aspect of the other lobes.

item.label: Frontal lobe
item.name: Frontal lobe
item.description: The frontal lobe is the most anterior lobe of the cerebral hemisphere. It includes primary motor cortex, premotor cortex, supplementary motor cortex, frontal eye fields, prefrontal cortex and orbital cortex. Via connections with the dorsomedial nucleus of thalamus and elsewhere, it is associated with the limbic system.

item.label: Temporal lobe
item.name: Temporal lobe
item.description: The temporal lobe is the most inferior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres.  It is located below the lateral sulcus and anterior to the occipital lobe. Important structures within the temporal lobe include: auditory sensory and association cortex, part of the posterior language cortex, visual and higher-order association cortex, primary and association olfactory cortex, amygdala, hippocampus and the inferior or temporal horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Occipital lobe
item.name: Occipital lobe
item.description: The occipital lobe is the most posterior lobe of the cerebral hemispheres. It is clinically important because it includes the primary and association visual cortex.

item.label: Olfactory bulb & tract
item.name: Olfactory tract
item.description: The olfactory bulb and tract are located on the ventral aspect of the frontal lobes in the olfactory sulcus.  Small-diameter olfactory nerve fibers (CN I) exit the olfactory epithelium, transit the cribriform plate and terminate in the olfactory bulb.  The olfactory tract continues on to the brain where it divides into the lateral and medial stria. The lateral olfactory stria travels across the lateral aspect of the anterior perforated substance and then bends medially toward the uncus.  The medial olfactory stria turns medially behind the paraolfactory area and ends in the subcallosal gyrus.

item.label: Commissure,Corpus call,Splenium
item.name: Corpus callosum
item.description: The splenium is the thick and rounded posterior aspect of the corpus callosum.  These commissural axons interconnect the occipital and temporal regions of the cerebral hemispheres.

item.label: Diencephalon
item.name: Diencephalon
item.description: Developmentally, the diencephalon and telencephalon are derived from the most anterior aspect of the developing neural tube, i.e. the prosencephalon. It includes the thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus and subthalamus. The retina, optic nerve and tract and neurohypophysis are also considered to be part of the diencephalon since they are formed as outgrowths from the diencephalon.

item.label: Thalamus
item.name: Thalamus
item.description: The thalamus is a large collection of nuclei that have major connections with the cerebral cortex involving both sensory and motor functions. Some thalamic nuclei have very specific connections relative to visual, auditory and somatosensory afferents and their projection to specific areas of cerebral cortex, while other nuclei have more general inputs and connections with association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Medial geniculate nucleus
item.name: Medial geniculate
item.description: The medial geniculate thalamic nucleus (MGN) deals with hearing.  It receives input from the cochlea via the cochlear nuclei, lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus. It projects to primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (transverse temporal or Heschl's gyri) via the sublenticular part of the internal capsule.

item.label: Lateral geniculate nucleus
item.name: Lateral geniculate
item.description: The lateral geniculate thalamic nucleus (LGN) deals with vision.  It receives input from the retina via the optic nerve and tract. It projects to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe (cuneus and lingual gyri) via the geniculocalcarine tract.  The geniculocalcarine tract is AKA the optic radiation and travels in both the sublenticular and retrolentricular portions of the internal capsule.

item.label: Hypothalamus
item.name: Hypothalamus
item.description: The hypothalamus is the most inferior of the four divisions of the diencephalon. While quite small, it has multiple important functions. It is the central control center for the autonomic nervous system, part of the limbic system, exerts a powerful influence on pituitary function and generally is responsible for maintaining homeostasis. It consists of multiple nuclei organized into three regions: anterior (suprachiasmatic, supraoptic and paraventricular), tuberal (dorsomedial, ventromedial and arcuate) and posterior (mammillary and posterior).

item.label: Mammillary bodies
item.name: Mammillary bodies
item.description: The mammillary bodies are part of the posterior hypothalamus.  They appear from the ventral view of the brain as a pair of rounded elevations. Primary circuitry involves input from the hippocampus via the fornix and output to the anterior nucleus of thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract. They are part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Infundibular stalk
item.name: Infundibular stalk
item.description: The infundibulum is the hollow, funnel-like stalk of the pituitary gland or hypophysis. It extends from the medial eminence of the hypothalamus to the posterior lobe of the pituitary. Embryologicaly, it and the posterior pituitary are derived from a ventral outgrowth of the diencephalon.

item.label: Midbrain
item.name: Midbrain
item.description: The midbrain is AKA the mesencephalon. Within its parts (tectum, tegmentum, substantia nigra and cerebral crus or basis pedunculi), it contains cranial nerve nuclei, all of the clinically important ascending and descending tracts, etc. It is traversed by the cerebral aqueduct or aqueduct of Sylvius. It originates developmentally from the mesencephalon.

item.label: Tectum
item.name: Tectum
item.description: The tectum is that portion of the midbrain located above the cerebral aqueduct.  It includes the superior and inferior colliculi which are AKA the quadrigeminal bodies.

item.label: Superior colliculus
item.name: Superior colliculus
item.description: The superior colliculi are paired, rounded structures on the superior surface of the rostral midbrain formed by the laminated or layered nuclei of the superior colliculi. Along with the paired inferior colliculi in the caudal midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The superior colliculus receives input from the retina and visual cortex and sends its output to the pulvinar of the thalamus, and plays a role in controlling eye movements, etc..

item.label: Superior brachium
item.name: Superior brachium
item.description: The brachium of the superior colliculus is AKA the superior brachium. It is a band of nerve fibers carrying information to the superior colliculus and pretectal area from the retina and visual cerebral cortex.

item.label: Tegmentum
item.name: Tegmentum
item.description: The tegmentum is that portion of the midbrain that lies between the cerebral aqueduct and the crus cerebri.  It includes the major ascending sensory tracts (medial lemniscus, spinothalamic), the red nucleus and the substantia nigra.

item.label: Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Cerebral crus
item.name: Cerbral crus
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Lateral ventricles
item.name: Lateral ventricles
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Cerebral aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.
